notes: All-new ninth-generation Camry. All models now hybrid or turbo. Standard 2.5L hybrid with 232 hp combined. Optional 2.5L turbo I4 with AWD produces 300 hp. Enhanced hybrid system requires hybrid-trained technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Camry article, January 2025 revision.

Compact crossover based on Corolla platform (TNGA-C). Available with conventional or hybrid powertrain. Fills gap between C-HR and RAV4. Hybrid system requires hybrid-trained service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Corolla Cross article, January 2025 revision.

Crown nameplate returns to North America as lifted sedan/crossover. All-wheel drive standard. Hybrid powertrains only. 2.4L turbo hybrid produces 340 hp combined. Premium Toyota flagship. Hybrid complexity requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Crown article, January 2025 revision.

Plug-in hybrid variant of RAV4. 302 hp combined output. 42 miles electric-only range. 18.1 kWh battery pack. 0-60 mph in 5.7 seconds. Fastest RAV4 ever. PHEV system requires plug-in hybrid trained technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota RAV4 article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation Highlander on TNGA-K platform. Three-row seating for 8. Available with V6 or hybrid powertrain. Hybrid uses 2.5L I4 with electric motors. Hybrid system requires specialized service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Highlander article, January 2025 revision.

Larger three-row variant of Highlander. Based on extended TNGA-K platform. Available with turbo I4 or turbo hybrid. Hybrid produces 362 hp combined. Seating for up to 8. Hybrid and turbo systems require specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Grand Highlander article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation Sienna. All models now hybrid-only. 2.5L I4 hybrid produces 245 hp combined. AWD available. Only hybrid minivan in North America. Seven or eight-passenger seating. Hybrid system requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Sienna article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation Sequoia on TNGA-F platform. Twin-turbo V6 hybrid produces 437 hp and 583 lb-ft torque. Shares platform with Tundra. Three-row seating for 8. Maximum towing 9,520 lbs. Hybrid twin-turbo complexity requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Sequoia article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation Tacoma on TNGA-F platform. All-new turbocharged powertrains. Optional hybrid i-FORCE MAX produces 326 hp combined. Available in Access Cab or Double Cab. Maximum towing 6,500 lbs. Hybrid turbo systems require specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Tacoma article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 3.5L Twin-Turbo V6 Hybrid i-FORCE MAX (437 hp combined)
notes: Third-generation Tundra on TNGA-F platform. Twin-turbo V6 replaces V8. Optional hybrid i-FORCE MAX produces 437 hp and 583 lb-ft. Available in Double Cab or CrewMax. Maximum towing 12,000 lbs. Hybrid twin-turbo complexity requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Tundra article, January 2025 revision.

Redesigned Land Cruiser returns to North America. Based on TNGA-F platform. Hybrid turbo I4 produces 326 hp combined. Traditional body-on-frame construction. Off-road focused with locking differentials. Hybrid turbo systems require specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Land Cruiser article, January 2025 revision.

Toyota's first mass-market battery electric vehicle. Co-developed with Subaru (Solterra). 71.4 kWh battery pack. Up to 252-mile range (FWD). 228-mile range (AWD). High-voltage EV system requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota bZ4X article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth-generation Prius with bold new styling. Available as hybrid or plug-in hybrid (Prime). PHEV has 13.6 kWh battery, 44 miles electric range. Improved performance and handling. Solar roof option. Hybrid and PHEV systems require specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Prius article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth-generation Supra returns after 17-year hiatus. Co-developed with BMW Z4. BMW B58 inline-six engine. Manual transmission announced for 2023+. Performance-oriented sports car. Turbocharged complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Supra article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation 86 sports car. Co-developed with Subaru (BRZ). Subaru-sourced 2.4L boxer engine. Manual transmission available. Lightweight rear-drive sports car. Affordable performance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota 86 article, January 2025 revision.
